etymology.description: 言(言) (yán, "speech") + 永(永) (yǒng, "long") = using words for a long duration -> chant; eulogize
etymology.interpretation: The combination of 言(言) (yán, "speech") and 永(永) (yǒng, "long") suggests the idea of speaking or singing at length, reflecting the meaning of chanting or eulogizing.
etymology.simplification: 詠(詠) was simplified to 咏(詠) by replacing 言(言) (yán, "speech") with 口(口) (kǒu, "mouth") to maintain the semantic focus on utterance while reducing the stroke count.

examples.chinese: 王羲之咏书法(王羲之詠書法)，表达情怀(表達情懷)。
examples.pinyin: Wáng Xīzhī yǒng shūfǎ, biǎodá qínghuái.
examples.english: Wang Xizhi chants about calligraphy, expressing his deep sentiments.

examples.chinese: 人们在纪念日咏颂英雄(人們在紀念日詠頌英雄)。
examples.english: On memorial days, people eulogize heroes.
